items.title: After Rocket Attack, an Israeli City Seems Resigned to More in the Future
items.abstract: Intense fighting with Gaza has heightened concerns about safety in Rishon LeZion and seems to have renewed the sentiment among residents of the unlikeliness of a long-term solution in their lifetimes.

items.title: A Hidden Warrior in the Park
items.abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A new acquaintance finds a bronze statue of an American Indian in a trash can in Carl Schurz Park.

items.title: City Housing Projects Call For Environmental Help
items.abstract: Housing project residents say the city encouraged them to “go green,” but did little to help them and in some circumstances, stood in their way.

items.title: Together a Century, City and Oil Giant Hit a Rough Patch
items.abstract: Chevron has spent millions in recent years trying to shore up its relationship with Richmond, Calif., but many residents still oppose the company’s efforts to repair a refinery hit by a fire.

items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: Woman’s Death in Queens Is City’s First Homicide of 2016
items.abstract: The police at first said there was “no apparent trauma” in the death of Joceline Romo, 19, before the medical examiner’s office ruled it was a homicide.

items.title: ‘Design Thinking’ for a Better You
items.abstract: A strategy called “design thinking” has helped numerous entrepreneurs and engineers develop successful new products and businesses. But can design thinking help you create healthful habits?

items.title: Bitter Debate Over Nuclear Power Simmers in Rural South Korea
items.abstract: In 2010, three villages agreed to give up their land to make room for a power plant, plunging the area into a battle over whether the plant would be a savior or a death knell.

items.title: A Boutique for the Great Outdoors and the Urban Wild
items.abstract: Snow Peak, newly opened in Manhattan, is more than a camping store.

items.title: New York City’s High School Graduation Rate Tops 70%
items.abstract: The announcement, which also noted that just over 78 percent of state students earned a diploma, came as state officials met to consider changes in graduation requirements.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Bright Spot for N.Y.’s Struggling Schools: Pre-K
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s broader plan for public schools has been disappointing, but his universal pre-K initiative shows steady improvement.

items.title: David Silva, Manchester City’s Key Piece, Is Now More Valuable Than Ever
items.abstract: As City tries to keep Liverpool in sight in the Premier League standings, it will turn, as it often does, to Silva to drive it forward.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: Where Did Rents Rise the Most in 2018?
items.abstract: Small American cities may not have the highest rents, but they did see the biggest percentage increases over the past year.

items.title: City Schools Are ‘Staying Open,’ Mayor Eric Adams Says
items.abstract: But the spike in Omicron cases has created trepidation for many parents.

items.title: How to Design a Home Gym That You’ll Actually Use
items.abstract: As the pandemic rages on, the safest place to work out is at home. Here’s how to create a personal gym you’ll want to spend time in.

items.title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
items.abstract: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.

items.title: A Rising Designer Brings Hip-Hop to Homeware
items.abstract: Sean Brown is the creative force behind Curves, a home décor brand inspired by African American pop culture. “I always aim to celebrate Blackness,” he said.

items.title: When Production Design Plays a Supporting Role
items.abstract: The visual environments of “West Side Story,” “The Humans” and “Nightmare Alley” feel as alive as the actors.
